citations.narrative:
An area along the front side of the perimeter fence had an 8.5 inch gap observed between the ground and bottom of the
fence. While the facility historically uses rocks beneath the fence line to maintain its integrity, the substrate has become
displaced, resulting in the gap present during today’s inspection.
Having a perimeter fence in place protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons from
going through it or under it, permitting contact with the animals in the facility. Additionally, it serves as a secondary
containment system for the animals in the facility.
The perimeter fence must be of sufficient distance from the outside of the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact
between animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter fence. Non-dangerous animals
housed in outdoor facilities require a 6-foot-tall perimeter fence around their enclosure and must be at least 3-feet away
from any enclosures or buildings, unless an approved variance has been issued in writing by the Administrator.
The facility corrected during the inspection.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant and facility representatives.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by June 30, 2025, or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
An area along the front side of the perimeter fence had an 8.5 inch gap observed between the ground and bottom of the 
fence. While the facility historically uses rocks beneath the fence line to maintain its integrity, the substrate has become 
displaced, resulting in the gap present during today’s inspection. 
 
Having a perimeter fence in place protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized persons from 
going through it or under it, permitting contact with the animals in the facility. Additionally, it serves as a secondary 
containment system for the animals in the facility.  
 
The perimeter fence must be of sufficient distance from the outside of the primary enclosure to prevent physical contact 
between animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside the perimeter fence. Non-dangerous animals 
housed in outdoor facilities require a 6-foot-tall perimeter fence around their enclosure and must be at least 3-feet away 
from any enclosures or buildings, unless an approved variance has been issued in writing by the Administrator. 
 
The facility corrected during the inspection. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant and facility representatives. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by June 30, 2025, or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
 n
